Review The dynamic behaviors of heterogeneous interfaces in electrocatalytic CO2 reduction Shenyu Shen a Qingfeng Guo b Tiantian Wu a * Yaqiong Su a * a School of Chemistry, Engineering Research Center of Energy Storage Materials and Devices of Ministry of Education, National Innovation Platform (Center) for Industry-Education Integration of Energy Storage Technology, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, Shaanxi, China School of Chemistry Engineering Research Center of Energy Storage Materials and Devices of Ministry of Education National Innovation Platform (Center) for Industry-Education Integration of Energy Storage Technology Xi'an Jiaotong University Xi'an Shaanxi 710049 China School of Chemistry, Engineering Research Center of Energy Storage Materials and Devices of Ministry of Education, National Innovation Platform (Center) for Industry-Education Integration of Energy Storage Technology, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, Shaanxi, China b Huanghe Science and Technology College, Zhengzhou 450063, Henan, China Huanghe Science and Technology College Zhengzhou Henan 450063 China Huanghe Science and Technology College, Zhengzhou 450063, Henan, China * Corresponding author The electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) is a highly promising renewable energy technology that can convert greenhouse gases into valuable fuels and chemicals. However, under ordinary operating conditions, significant dynamic evolution behavior occurs on the catalyst surface, which is mainly manifested as surface morphology evolution and property changes, eventually leading to changes in the active sites of the reaction, affecting selectivity and efficiency. To develop efficient electrocatalytic systems with excellent performance, an essential prerequisite is to understand the underlying mechanism of surface dynamic evolution. Studying the influence of the external environment on dynamic evolution is as important as studying the intrinsic structural properties of catalysts. In this review, we first introduce the concept of dynamic evolution and then emphasize the influence of the external environment (applied potential, temperature, electrolyte, and impurities) on CO2RR dynamic evolution. We also address the use of operando characterization techniques and pulsed CO2 electrolysis methods for monitoring and controlling dynamic evolution behaviors under working conditions, along with theoretical methods, including ab initio calculations and machine learning that can simulate dynamic behavior. Finally, we present several current challenges and prospects for the development of techniques for controlling the CO2RR dynamic evolution. Graphical Abstract This review summarizes research progress on the dynamic evolution behavior of heterogeneous interfaces in electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reactions. These include the classification of dynamic evolution behavior, external environmental factors, experimental operando characterization techniques, pulsed CO2 electrolysis, and theoretical simulation methods. Keywords CO2 reduction reaction Dynamic behavior Active site External environment Electrocatalysis 1 Introduction Since the Industrial Revolution, excess CO2 emissions have caused many serious environmental and social problems, including climate change, a rise in the sea level, and ocean acidification. Carbon neutrality has become a global goal for maintaining the ecological health of Earth [1]. Using captured CO2 as a raw material to produce organic fuels can help alleviate these problems by reducing CO2 pollution as well as the use of fossil fuels [2]. CO2 is one of the most stable and inert compounds, owing to its high C=O bond energy of 750 kJ mol−1. Compared to thermal catalytic conversion, which requires high temperature and pressure, the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) driven by renewable electricity is an attractive alternative because it can convert CO2 into sustainable fuels and feedstock [3–5]. The CO2RR has contributed significantly to this aspect. However, multiple complex electron-proton transfer steps are inevitable. Furthermore, the CO2RR pathway can vary depending on both the electrocatalyst employed and the experimental conditions. This variability can lead to diverse product distributions, including those of carbon monoxide (CO), methane (CH4), and ethylene (C2H4). Notably, the competing hydrogen evolution reactions (HERs) occur simultaneously [6,7]. In most studies, transition-metal catalysts have demonstrated superior performance in CO2 reduction. Based on the different products generated, the catalysts can be divided into three main categories: (1) Ni, Fe, Pt, and Ti, which mainly produce H2; (2) Au, Ag, Zn, Pd, and Ga, which primarily generate CO; and (3) Pb, Hg, Tl, In, Sn, and Cd, which predominantly produce formic acid. Another catalyst based on hexagonal Co nanosheets selectively converts CO2 into ethanol and CH3CHO [8]. However, copper is a special exception because it can reduce CO2 to 18 diverse compounds and hydrocarbons [9]. The diversity of the intermediates and reduction products also leads to poor product selectivity, with the dynamic evolution of the catalyst being an important factor responsible for this result. Dynamic evolution is influenced by various factors, not limited to the intrinsic properties of the catalyst, which include the chemical composition of the catalyst, size of the material, facets, and curvature. The external environment (e.g., electrolyte and temperature) is another factor that must be considered. Selectivity should not be regarded only as an inherent property of a catalyst but rather as a result of the interplay between the catalyst and external environment [10]. By revealing the dynamic evolution behavior of catalyst surfaces, we can enhance our understanding of the active sites and advance the design and development of more sophisticated catalysts. Many relevant studies have focused on the surface and subsurface active sites of catalysts, whose properties are mainly affected by factors such as the chemical composition, crystal facets, surface morphology, particle size, oxidation state, defect engineering, and atomic coordination environment [11]. More specifically, the properties of heterogeneous catalysts can change through a variety of phenomena such as Ostwald maturation, oxidation, and dissolution; therefore, an understanding of the active sites of heterogeneous catalysts to the same extent as those of molecular homogeneous catalysts remains a challenge [12,13]. In terms of experimental techniques, researchers have made great progress in developing in situ and operando characterization techniques, enabling real-time monitoring of dynamic evolution and the capture of intermediates [5,14]. In particular, a promising pulsed electrolysis technique is expected to directly manipulate dynamic evolution [15]. In addition, many computational methods, including ab initio calculations and machine learning, play an important role in simulating the dynamic evolution behavior of catalysts [16]. These methods are instrumental in studying the reaction mechanisms of catalysts and optimizing their performance. In this review, we describe the dynamic behavior of heterogeneous interfaces during electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. First, the principles and classifications of dynamic evolution are introduced. Next, based on the latest developments in the dynamic evolution of typical catalysts, the influences of external factors on the dynamic evolution of CO2RR, including the applied potential, temperature, electrolyte, and impurities, are discussed in detail. Subsequently, a series of operando characterization techniques that can monitor changes in the active sites during real-time operation are summarized, and a discussion on pulsed CO2 electrolysis and ab initio calculations, along with machine learning methods, is also included. Finally, we summarize the latest progress in dynamic evolution, current challenges, and prospects for future development. 2 Fundamental principles of dynamic evolution Ever since Taylor proposed the concept of “active site” in 1925 [17], it has become a pivotal subject in the study of reaction mechanisms. Under working conditions, the structure of a catalyst can undergo dynamic evolution, leading to the formation of elusive active sites. Therefore, understanding the concept of “dynamic evolution” is crucial. Extensive research has been conducted on the underlying principles of dynamic evolution from both thermodynamic and kinetic perspectives. Lai et al. [18] reviewed the principles and progress of the dynamic evolution of CO2RR active sites. Zhang et al. [19] focused on the dynamic evolution of defects in electrocatalysts. Zhao et al. [20] reviewed the structural evolution, active sites, and stability of heterogeneous catalysts. Based on the current research, the dynamic evolution behavior can be classified into two primary categories: (1) surface morphology change and (2) property change. The main reason for this morphological change is atomic rearrangement, whereas changes in the oxidation state and coordination environment are primarily responsible for variations in the chemical state properties [12]. Here, we briefly elucidate the dynamic behavior of the CO2 reduction reaction, including its principal classifications (morphology and property changes) and exemplary manifestations. 2.1 Catalyst morphology change The change in catalyst morphology refers to the positional rearrangement and migration of atoms on the catalyst surface, driven by thermodynamics and kinetics. In terms of thermodynamics, the driving force for atomic rearrangement primarily depends on the change in Gibbs free energy (ΔG mig) before and after the rearrangement [21]. The more negative the ΔG mig value, the easier the atomic migration. The driving force for atomic rearrangement is determined by the migration energy barrier [21]. The migration energy barrier is primarily influenced by the intrinsic properties of the catalyst, with a lower barrier increasing the likelihood of atomic migration. Atomic migration at the microscopic level can result in significant changes in the macroscopic surface structure of catalysts, presenting various phenomena, including, but not limited to, phase transitions, changes in elemental composition, and particle size. The performance of copper catalysts can be improved by the construction of multi-metallic systems that promote synergistic effects [22–24]. In this regard, AgCu bimetallic catalysts have shown promise. Time-sequential electron microscopy and elemental mapping studies have demonstrated the high atomic migration of copper in the CO2RR on AgCu surfaces [25]. Cu atoms exhibit a propensity to migrate towards the catalyst surface, where they may undergo dissociation or recombination into new configurations. Interestingly, both Ag and Cu exhibit a tendency towards phase separation, leading to the formation of a stable two-phase structure with segregated elements (Fig. 1(a) ). In a recent study by Kuang et al. [26], a disordered CuAu nanoalloy (d-CuAu) was proven to have a Cu-rich surface structure owing to atomic rearrangement in the process of CO2RR, which is the root of its poor stability and product selectivity. In contrast, the highly ordered CuAu (o-CuAu) exhibits good stability and selectivity owing to strong atomic interactions. These findings also underscore how dynamic evolution can have both beneficial and detrimental effects on the CO2RR. An effective approach for stabilizing Cu with silica has been proposed to avoid negative effects such as deactivation caused by catalyst reconstruction, particularly for Cu catalysts [27]. The synthesized CuSiO x amorphous nanotube catalysts exhibit excellent resistance to reconstruction (Fig. 1(b)) and high selectivity towards CH4 products (Figs. 1(c) and (d)). This can be attributed to the strong interaction between Cu and silica, which ensures that the Cu–O–Si interfacial site retains remarkable stability during the CO2RR. In addition to changes in catalyst morphology, particle size also plays a crucial role in catalytic activity. Metal nanoparticles (NPs) dissolve and redeposit (Ostwald ripening), which is a prime example of this phenomenon [28]. Changes in particle size can significantly alter reaction selectivity. In a study conducted by Jung et al. [29], cubic Cu2O crystal particles of size 20 nm underwent in situ electrochemical fragmentation under a negative potential on the surface of nanocrystals, forming small particles of size 2–4 nm (Figs. 1(e) and (f)). The fragmented nanoparticles inhibited HER activity and promoted C–C coupling (Fig. 1(g)). In the study conducted by Lei et al. [30], under the negative potential of CO2RR, a change in the particle size of the catalyst was observed. The oxide crystals in HQ-Cu (containing Cu, Cu2O, and CuO) and the hydroxide crystals in AN-Cu (containing Cu and Cu(OH)2) were both reduced and fragmented into small irregular Cu grains, whereas no fragmentation was observed in electropolished Cu. This fragmentation process promotes C–C coupling and enhances the selectivity towards C2+ products. These observations highlight the critical role of nanoparticle size in determining catalytic performance, emphasizing the importance of paying careful attention to nanoparticle characteristics when designing catalysts for specific applications. 2.2 Surface property change Changes in a catalyst's surface properties mainly refer to changes in its chemical state. In Cu-catalyzed CO2RR, in situ grazing-incidence X-ray absorption spectroscopy (GIXAS) has revealed the full reduction of the surface oxide layer to a metallic Cu state before the onset potential (Figs. 2(a) and (b) ) [31]. Research on the oxidation states of Cu has provided valuable insights [32–37]. Theoretical calculations and experimental investigations have substantiated the importance of the coexistence of Cu+ and Cu0 in the formation of C2 products [36,37]. These two oxidation states have been shown to act synergistically, resulting in improved efficiency and selectivity. In addition to the commonly studied copper-based catalysts, the surface properties of other metals change during the reactions. Through X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (XAFS) experiments (Figs. 2(c) and (d)), zinc, a significant catalyst for CO2 reduction to CO, has been found to contain residual cationic species (with a structure similar to that of Zn hydroxide) in its catalytic form [38]. The coordination environment at the active sites directly affects the efficiency and selectivity of the reaction. Recent reports have demonstrated that a catalyst featuring dispersed single-atom iron sites can achieve exceptionally low overpotentials (as low as 80 mV) for CO production [39]. Operando X-ray adsorption spectroscopy revealed that the active sites of Fe3+ can coordinate with the pyrrolic nitrogen (N) atoms of the N-doped carbon support, resulting in a higher activity for CO2 conversion compared to traditional Fe2+ sites. In2O3 is another noteworthy catalyst with a promising potential for the conversion of CO2 to methanol via hydrogenation. During the activation stage of this process, a slight decrease in In–O coordination has been observed along with some degree of In2O3 reduction owing to the formation of oxygen vacancy sites (Figs. 2(e) and (f)) [40]. Notably, the activity of the catalysts is associated with the structural evolution of both the surface and bulk phases of the catalyst. Ren et al. [41] reported a study in which Cu2O nanocubes were found to undergo a series of structural and morphological transformations in an electrochemical environment. They transformed from dense nanocubes to nanocubes with rough surfaces to hollow shell structures, and finally evolved into smaller nanoparticle aggregates with a mixed phase of Cu and Cu oxides. The formation of dendritic nanoparticles favors the HER, while the Cu interconnects favor C–C coupling. During the 2-h CO2RR, the catalyst exhibited good stability towards selective ethylene production, suppressing the generation of C1 products. As the reaction proceeded, the FE of H2 gradually increased. Therefore, when considering the entire influence of dynamic evolution on reaction performance, both the surface and bulk phases must be considered. 3 External factors of dynamic evolution The dynamic evolution of catalysts results from the interplay between their inherent properties and external environmental factors. Their structural evolution is significantly influenced by their chemical composition [42], crystal facets [31,43], particle size [44], and curvature [42,45]. In multimetallic systems, the internal arrangement of atoms can lead to more complex alloying, dealloying, and even phase transitions than in monometallic systems [46,47]. However, external environmental factors, such as the applied potential, have notable effects on the electrocatalyst redox peaks [48,49], which play a vital role in the interfacial environment. Herein, we focus on the impact of external environmental factors on the dynamic evolution behavior of catalysts with regard to four distinct aspects: i) applied potential, ii) temperature, iii) electrolyte, and iv) impurities. By examining these variables, insights can be gained into the fundamental mechanisms driving catalyst evolution and how evolution might be controlled. 3.1 Applied potential The applied potential is the driving force for the reactants to overcome the free-energy barrier. This significantly affects the stability and selectivity of the catalyst. In the study reported by Han et al. [50], a reduction-oxidation-reduction (ROR) electrochemical treatment was designed. At a high oxidation potential, the ROR catalyst was conducive to the formation of rich grain boundaries (Fig. 3(a) ), promoting the generation of *COOH derivatives. In contrast, at low oxidation potentials, the deficiency of the ROR catalyst at the grain boundaries (Fig. 3(b)) causes the selective production of *OCHO derivatives [50]. When the electrode potential is lower than 0 V (vs. NHE), the metal electrode undergoes cathodic corrosion [51]. Cathodic corrosion is reductive in nature and causes morphological changes in metal electrodes. This process occurs anisotropically and produces specific surface sites. For example, during the CO2RR, the Cu surface undergoes anisotropic reconstruction. Polycrystalline copper undergoes stepwise surface reconstruction into Cu(100) [52]. Moreover, the applied potential can cause catalysts to degrade easily during the electrolysis process and thus reduce their stability, which is usually considered an unfavorable dynamic evolution. The primary driving force for the degradation of Cu nanocubes (CuNCs) is negative potential [53]. Different potentials can lead to distinct mechanisms for CO2 reduction and alter the product distribution. Relevant calculations have confirmed that, on Cu surfaces, the sequential electron-proton transfer (SEPT) mechanism predominates at working potentials, whereas the concerted proton-electron transfer (CPET) mechanism becomes more prominent at more negative potentials (Fig. 3(c)) [54]. Through theoretical DFT calculations, researchers discovered that the energy barrier for the electron transfer steps in the SEPT mechanism exhibits a reversed region as the applied potential decreases. This phenomenon is attributed to the rapid increase in Pauli repulsion during the physisorption of CO2 with decreasing applied potential. Under normal working conditions, the applied potential can induce a shift in the electrocatalyst redox peaks. Consequently, changes occur in both the oxidation state and structure of the catalyst. Kim et al. [52] found that under CO2RR conditions, pristine polycrystalline Cu undergoes the following transformation: Cu(pc) → Cu(pc)-[Cu(111)] → Cu(pc)-[Cu(100)] (Fig. 3(d)). This reconstruction process occurs because of the high negative electrode potential. This cathodic corrosion phenomenon can be observed in both KOH and KHCO3 solutions [55]. Notably, surface reconstruction from Cu(pc) to Cu(100) specifically occurred in the presence of CO2 molecules, and this reconstruction increased as the applied potential became more negative [31]. Before the initiation of the CO2RR, the copper oxide layer on the surface of Cu(pc) was reduced to metallic Cu, which remained in a metallic state during the reaction. However, under the same conditions, the native monocrystalline Cu(111) surface did not undergo reconstruction even after 4 h, indicating high stability [56], whereas Cu(110) was replaced stepwise through the following evolution: Cu(110) → Cu(110)-d[Cu(110)] → Cu(110)-d[Cu(111)] → Cu(110)- [Cu(100)]. With regard to Cu(100), an extensive study on its behavior during the CO2RR in a 0.1 mol L−1 KHCO3 solution found that the surface evolution depends on the applied potential [57]. The surface morphology can transform from granular to smoothly curved with mounds and pits or structures with rectangular terraces exposed. Moreover, the presence of CO on the surface can induce preferential reconstruction of the step edges of Cu(100) along the <001> direction [58]. 3.2 Temperature The Arrhenius formula defines the rate constant of atomic migration as follows [18,21]: D mig = D 0exp(–E mig/RT) where D 0 is a pre-exponential factor, E mig is the atomic migration energy barrier, T is the absolute temperature, and D mig is the migration rate constant. The temperature has a direct effect on the rate of atomic migration. Operating at higher temperatures leads to increased vibrational energy and amplitude, which enables a lower barrier for atomic migration [18]. Temperature is a crucial factor that affects electrochemical reactions. However, under practical conditions, the actual temperature of the reaction may not remain at ambient temperature owing to heat loss and other factors [59,60]. Electrolyzers are frequently used at elevated temperatures [61]. The influence of temperature on CO2RR has been widely studied [61–66]. In the case of copper-based catalysts, studies by Hori et al. [62] revealed that increasing the electrolyte temperature (0–40 °C) in 0.5 mol L−1 KHCO3 can enhance the Faradaic efficiency of H2 and C2H4, while reducing the selectivity for CH4. In more recent studies, Koper et al. [61] probed the intrinsic reasons for the temperature-dependent selectivity of the Cu-catalyzed CO2RR. Within the temperature range of 18 to 48 °C, C2+ products exhibit higher Faradaic efficiency, consistent with earlier research (Fig. 4(a) ). As the temperature rises from 48 to 70 °C, the HER reaction becomes more competitive than CO2RR (Fig. 4(b)), leading to a decrease in CO2RR activity and primarily yielding CO and HCOOH as products (Fig. 4(c)). At low temperatures, CO surface coverage, local pH, and kinetics are the dominant factors. At elevated temperatures, the structural evolution of the Cu-based catalyst surface is the primary cause. At 70 °C, compared to lower temperatures, a significant change is observed in the results of Pb underpotential deposition (UPD) cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests, indicating a substantial change in the copper surface. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) imaging also supports this result, as the catalyst surface becomes smoother with increasing temperature (Figs. 4(d)–(f)). This phenomenon may be attributed to faster O2 diffusion to the surface at high temperatures, promoting Cu2O to be reduced and altering the properties of the catalyst. Furthermore, temperature is also related to oxidation kinetics [64]. During catalytic reactions, Cu and its oxides undergo reduction [67,68], oxidation [69], and alloying [70]. In situ investigations have focused on the oxidation of Cu [71]. The oxidation process of Cu involves the initial nucleation of oxides on the thin film, subsequent diffusion along the Cu surface, and the ultimate formation of Cu2O islands [64]. From 300 to 500 °C, the oxidation mechanism remains the same, with an increase in oxidation rate. In an oxygen atmosphere of 2 Pa at 300 °C, Cu2O was unilaterally formed from Cu after 20 min. After 30 min, approximately half of the particles were oxidized. For some nanoparticles, Cu/Cu2O interface termination was observed via phase separation. Subsequently, the particles were completely oxidized over time. Cu nanoparticles reduced at room temperature underwent a similar oxidative process but exhibited a degree of hollowing between Cu and Cu2O. A high-temperature solid oxide electrolysis cell in which a particular dual-phase composite electrode consisting of La(Sr)Cr(Mn)O3 (LSCM) and Ce(Mn,Fe)O2 (CMF) can enhance the activity of CO2RR [72] was used. At 850 °C and a voltage of 1.5 V, the electrolytic performance of the electrode reached 2.64 A cm−2, owing to the increase in the number of active sites and oxygen vacancies on the CMF. In contrast to increasing the catalytic activity at high temperatures, some studies have shown that lowering the temperature of the electrode can improve methane selectivity, although this often significantly increases the overpotential. Specifically, lowering the surface temperature of the electrode increases the residence time of the intermediate CO, resulting in a higher selective generation of CH4 [66]. Overall, manipulating the environmental temperature as a tactical strategy to enhance the reaction performance alongside traditional catalyst property engineering requires further investigation to unlock its full potential. 3.3 Electrolyte Electrocatalytic reactions occur in the electric double layer (EDL) between the solid electrode and the electrolyte. As the reaction medium for the CO2RR, electrolytes are intimately linked to the interfacial environment of the reaction, particularly in terms of pH and cations. The presence of metal and organic cations in the electrolyte has a significant impact on the activity and selectivity of the CO2RR [73–75]. The electrolyte influences the behavior of the reactive species and, consequently, affects the overall reaction process. Water is commonly used for electrochemical reactions. However, different electrolytes exhibit distinctive solvent effects. For example, they may act as aprotic solvents, which effectively suppress the hydrogen evolution reaction. Furthermore, significant progress has been made in the development of novel polymer electrolytes [76,77]. Eikerling et al. [78,79] developed continuum models to better estimate local (dynamic) reaction conditions. This hierarchical model considers multistep reaction kinetics, surface charge effects, and mass-transport phenomena [79]. For the CO2RR on Ag, at higher overpotentials, the CO current density decreases owing to the combined effects of mass transport, surface charge, and pH increase. The interactions of different adsorbates also lead to a decrease in CO current density. Additionally, the local reaction environment can be tuned by changing the bicarbonate concentration, cation size, and CO2 pressure. Estimating the local reaction interface can help us understand the influence of external environmental factors on dynamic evolution. In this discussion, we focus primarily on the influence of water-based electrolytes and pH on the CO2RR. 3.3.1 pH effects The interaction between the electrochemical effects arising from the promotion of atomic migration by adsorbed reaction intermediates and the electromigration-induced electrical effects play a vital role in driving catalysts towards structural evolution [42]. The pH value has a significant impact on the formation of active species as well as on the current density of the CO2RR catalyst. Furthermore, it can shift the redox potential to the SHE scale [80], thereby altering both the selectivity and activity of the reaction. In the study reported by Hori et al. [81], the partial current for CH4 formation was found to be proportional to proton activity. Building upon this research, Koper et al. [82] conducted further investigations into the impact of pH on the copper-catalyzed CO2RR, revealing different reaction pathways for ethylene formation on different facets of Cu. As the pH varied, methane and ethylene exhibited different onset potentials (Fig. 5(a) ). For Cu(111) at a pH of 7, the reaction pathways for methane and ethylene have the same onset potentials, both involving the intermediate CHO*. However, on Cu(100) at a pH of 7, the potential for ethylene was lower than that for methane, indicating that CO undergoes dimerization to yield ethylene. In addition, pH had an influence on the competing HER. The highly active CO2RR enhanced the local pH near the catalytic surface, thereby suppressing the HER [83]. The value of pH has a direct impact on the surface of catalysts. Pourbaix diagrams (Fig. 5(b)) provide a comprehensive depiction of the stability of chemical species under different pH values and potential conditions, revealing the pH dependence of material stability [84]. In addition, pH can induce dynamic evolution owing to the interactions of H atoms with electrode surfaces. Under electroreduction conditions, the adsorption of hydrogen at a negative electrode potential can trigger the restructuring of Cu(100) (Figs. 5(c) and (d)) [84]. The formation of Cu–H bonds weakens the Cu–Cu bonds between the sublayers and top layers, which facilitates row-shifting in both thermodynamics and kinetics. When the coverage of H increases, Cu migration is enhanced. This phenomenon has been substantiated by the striped patterns observed in simulated and experimental scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) images. The protons in the electrolyte also act as reducing agents for Cu2O, promoting the formation of a metastable Cu–O–H phase on the catalyst surface (Fig. 5(e)) [41]. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations have shown that the stabilized Cu–O–H phase is derived from the Cu2O phase. The value of pH also has an indirect impact on the morphology of catalysts. At the potential of zero free charge (pzfc) [85], Cu(111) shows structural reconstruction at pH values of 11 and 13 (Figs. 5(f) and (g)) [86]. The position of pzfc in alkaline solutions determines the change in free excess metal charge, which can induce surface reconstruction. Under the influence of the induced positive charge, the distance between Cu atoms tends to widen, and the structure undergoes evolution. The pH value affects the dynamic evolution of the catalyst; moreover, the local pH is affected by the surface morphology of the catalyst [83]. In a study conducted by Yu et al., ultrathin and porous Bi nanosheets (Bi-PNSs) exhibited enhanced catalytic reactivity compared to smooth Bi nanoparticles (Bi-NPs). They provided more active sites for the CO2RR, thereby increasing the local pH and inhibiting the HER [83]. 3.3.2 Cation and anion effects Many studies have investigated the effects of different cations and anions on the selectivity of CO2RR [73–75,87–89]. According to the existing research, the activity of CO2RR for alkali metal cations increases in the order of Li+ < Na+ < K+ < Cs+ (Fig. 6(a) ) [87]. Monteiro et al. [88] demonstrated that the presence of metal cations in the electrolyte is necessary for the formation of CO on copper, gold, and silver electrodes (Figs. 6(b) and (c)). They further confirmed the role of cations through ab initio molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. Metal cations exhibit a stabilizing effect on CO2 adsorption and the formation of the key intermediate CO2 − [88]. The electrostatic interactions between the solvated metal cations in the outer Helmholtz plane and the adsorbed species with high dipole moments can also influence the selectivity of the products (Figs. 6(d–f)) [90]. In addition, local buffering at the interface and variations in the local electric field explain the mechanism underlying the cation effect [87]. In the case of bicarbonate-based electrolytes, which are commonly used in CO2RR, the bicarbonate anions (HCO3 −) play multiple roles. They not only serve as a pH buffer and source of protons but also actively participate in the reaction. The reactants of the CO2RR are derived from CO2 molecules that are in equilibrium with HCO3 − rather than from CO2 directly adsorbed on the surface of the solution [89]. Certain anions, however, can poison the catalyst and reduce its activity. For example, Pt-based catalysts are prone to phosphate and sulfate anion poisoning [91,92]. The presence of different cations and anions in electrolytes can facilitate diverse dynamic evolution behaviors on the surface of catalysts [93,94]. Jiang et al. [93] revealed that in CO2-saturated KHCO3 solution, bismuth oxide formate nanowires (BiOCOOH NWS) tend to undergo a transformation into a two-dimensional sheet structure. Subsequently, these sheets further reconstitute into larger ultrathin bismuth nanosheets with their surfaces covered by an amorphous oxide layer (Bi/BiO x NSs). In contrast, reconstruction occurs in HCOONa solutions saturated with Ar, resulting in the formation of rough and porous one-dimensional bismuth nanowires (Bi NWs). Halide anions can also contribute to the surface reconstruction of copper electrodes (Figs. 6(g–i)). A Cu film consisting of entangled Cu nanowires (Re–Cu–I) can be synthesized in the presence of I− [94]. This unique structure has hierarchical pores that enhance the local coverage of the CO* species on the surface, improving the selectivity and Faradaic efficiency of the C2 products (Fig. 6(j)). To summarize, further research is needed to understand the interactions between the anions and cations in electrolytes and the active sites. 3.4 Impurities effect Therefore, the influence of impurities on the dynamic behavior of the reaction system must be investigated. The presence of impurities in the reaction system is inevitable during actual electrochemical processes. These impurities can have various effects on the active sites within the catalytic environment, including catalyst poisoning, competitive adsorption of key intermediates, and changes in the reaction mechanism, ultimately influencing the reaction activity and selectivity [11]. Trace metal ions are considered impurities. Studies have shown that trace metal impurities in the electrolyte can negatively impact the performance of CO2RR [95,96]. For example, Hori et al. [96] found that Fe2+ impurities can deposit on the electrode surface, promoting the HER while adversely affecting the CO2RR. To solve this problem, viable methods include the use of a Pt black electrode for pre-electrolysis or pre-treating the electrolyte solution with chelators such as ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) for purification [96,97]. Another approach is the surface-restructuring strategy, in which foreign atoms induce the restructuring of the metal surface, refreshing the catalyst and maintaining its activity (Fig. 7(a) ) [98]. However, metal impurities do not always have negative impacts; sometimes they can even be designed as active components in catalysts. Kim et al. [99] designed a novel reaction system in which N-doped carbon catalysts could be “self-activated” in the presence of Fe impurities. This catalyst exhibits remarkable stability for up to 120 h. This is attributed to the interaction between the adsorbed Fe impurities and nitrogen species. Another type of impurity is gaseous impurity. In industrial applications, the feedstock for the CO2RR often contains gaseous impurities such as oxygen (O2), nitrogen oxides (NO x ), and sulfur oxides (SO x ) [100,101]. These impurities can cause additional side reactions [102–104]. NO x reacts with water to produce acidic products that promote HER [105]. The resulting nitrate (NO3 −) and nitrite (NO2 −) compete with CO2 for reduction [102,103]. Similarly, O2 competes with CO2 for electrons and promotes the formation of metal oxides [104,106], which can change the morphology and properties of the catalyst surface. Engelbrecht et al. [107] found that the presence of O2 in CO2 leads to the formation of Cu+ species, which enhances the Faraday efficiency of C2H4 production (Figs. 7(b) and (c)). Moreover, SO2 impurities hinder the CO2RR because of their thermodynamically favorable reduction. Although the effect of SO2 on Ag and Sn is reversible, it is irreversible for Cu. Calculations and TEM characterization (Fig. 7(d)) have revealed that SO2 induces the formation of Cu2S species on the copper surface [108]. Based on these studies, reactive carbon solutions have been developed to mitigate the toxic effects of flue gas impurities during CO2RR processes [109]. In summary, the changes in the surface morphology and properties of catalysts depend on the external environment. To better study the structure-performance relationship, experimental techniques, and theoretical methods have been developed to characterize, manipulate, and simulate structural evolution under working conditions. 4 Techniques for investigating dynamic evolution With the development of in situ/operando characterization techniques [5,110–114], such as optical spectroscopy, X-ray characterization techniques, and electron microscopy techniques, researchers can gain a better understanding of the active sites on catalyst surfaces during reactions. Furthermore, the CO2 pulsed electrolysis technique can manipulate dynamic evolution, enabling changes in the catalyst morphology or the formation of oxidized surface species [115–118]. This effectively influences the reactivity and selectivity of the CO2RR [119,120]. In addition, computational methods such as ab initio and machine learning have been extensively applied to simulate dynamic evolution [16]. In this section, we summarize the various experimental characterization techniques and theoretical simulation methods utilized to study the dynamic behavior of heterogeneous interfaces in the CO2RR. 4.1 Operando techniques 4.1.1 Optical spectroscopy techniques Spectroscopic characterization techniques primarily include infrared (IR) and Raman spectroscopy, which are commonly used to detect adsorbates on catalyst surfaces and characterize the surface and near-surface regions of the catalysts. Infrared spectroscopy can be affected by water absorption; therefore, attenuated total reflection infrared spectroscopy (ATR-IR) was developed, which is more suitable for CO2RR on a solid-liquid reaction interface. Compared with infrared spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy is less affected by water and can be used directly in aqueous solvents. Surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (SEIRAS) and surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) have addressed the issue of weak signal intensity in spectroscopic techniques. ATR-IR is an important tool for detecting intermediates and can detect the presence of multiple CO or CHO species, as well as COOH and COO− (Fig. 8(a) ), suggesting a stepwise transfer of protons and electrons during CO2 reduction [9,89]. The combination of SERS and isotopic labeling can detect the intermediates of the CO2RR, specifically bidentate and monodentate-adsorbed carbonates, in carbonate solutions (Figs. 8(b) and (c)) [121]. At more negative potentials, the presence of Cu–OH and Cu–C species has also been detected. Meng et al. [122] improved the operando Raman system, enabling better in situ and real-time recordings of weak Raman peaks (Figs. 8(d) and (e)). Their work revealed a correlation between the evolution of the surface structure and capacity fading of LiMn2O4. In a recent study by Liu et al. [123], 2D indium coordination polymers (In-CPs) were successfully transformed into elemental indium nanosheets. The reconstructed metallic indium exhibited high Faradaic efficiency towards formate and displayed superior stability compared to state-of-the-art indium-based electrocatalysts. The dynamic evolution of In-CPs during the preconstruction process was characterized using Raman spectroscopy, which revealed a gradual decrease in the intensity of three prominent Raman bands located at 1390, 1092, and 167 cm−1. This observation suggests a slow detachment of the ligand units from the metal framework. 4.1.2 X-ray characterization techniques X-ray characterization techniques commonly used in research include XAS, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and X-ray diffraction (XRD). Operando hard XAS is widely used to study the structural properties of active sites under working conditions, observe dynamic evolution processes, and analyze reaction mechanisms [110]. Soft XAS is mainly employed to detect the oxidation states of metals and metal-ligand interactions. Furthermore, the obtained XAFS spectra can be divided into XANES and EXAFS spectra. XANES provides information about the chemical states of the measured elements, whereas EXAFS offers details about the local atomic structures, such as the coordination number and bond lengths [5,110,124]. Under CO2RR conditions and using XANES analysis of In2O3 at different temperatures, Zhang et al. [125] observed that In2O3 was reduced with increasing temperature, whereas EXAFS analysis showed the generation of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface and a decrease in the atomistic orderliness (Figs. 9(a) and (b) ). XPS is another important surface characterization technique. By measuring the energy distribution of photoelectrons and Auger electrons emitted from the surface of the sample upon X-ray photon irradiation, XPS allows for the qualitative identification of elements and characterization of the electronic structure. Researchers have utilized XPS to investigate CuZn nanoparticles and observed a lack of metal leaching (Figs. 9(c) and (d)) [126]. XPS can characterize the evolution of catalyst surface properties by detecting the oxidation states of the elements. By studying the valence states of SnO2 and Sn3O(OH)2Cl2 after the CO2RR using XPS, distinct signals corresponding to the reduced Sn0 species can be clearly identified in the Sn 3d XPS spectrum [127]. This confirms that both SnO2 and Sn3O(OH)2Cl2 undergo reduction during the CO2RR. As a molecular-level characterization technique, XRD can be used to analyze crystal structure and composition. Chen et al. observed the structural evolution of Ag-Cu alloys using XRD (Fig. 9(e)) [25]. At the start of the CO2RR, the (111) peak assigned to Cu-rich grains gradually flattened, indicating Cu degradation from the catalyst and a decrease in crystallinity. The angle of the Ag-rich grain (111) peak decreased, suggesting the leaching of Cu dopants from the Ag-rich grains during the reaction process. In addition, Sang et al. [128] developed a Cu2P2O7 catalyst that could undergo reduction to metallic Cu and evolve into a highly porous structure under the CO2RR condition. The reconstructed catalyst exhibits abundant defects and low-coordinated sites, which facilitate CO adsorption and coupling, thereby lowering the reaction energy barrier for C2 product formation. The XRD spectra reveal characteristic changes in the Cu2P2O7 electrode after the CO2RR: the disappearance of the Cu2P2O7 phase and the appearance of peaks corresponding to Cu and Cu2O. 4.1.3 Microscopic imaging techniques Microscopic imaging techniques enable nanoscale observation of the surface structure, morphology, and composition of catalysts. These techniques primarily include TEM and scanning probe microscopy (SPM). The principle of TEM involves directing a high-energy electron beam onto a thin specimen, where the interactions between the electrons and atoms produce various images that reflect the structural information of the sample. To address the challenge of time-resolved evaluation of active sites at solid-liquid-gas interfaces, an improved operando (S)TEM technique was designed that allows real-time imaging of the surface structure evolution of catalysts [110]. HRTEM provides atomic-level resolution, which enables the observation of finer structures. Using the STEM-high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) technique, Luo et al. [41] showed that Cu2O nanocubes under CO2RR conditions gradually degrade starting from the surface and transform their cubic shape into aggregates of smaller nanoparticles (Fig. 10(a) ). SPM is a novel probe microscopy technology based on STM and atomic force microscopy (AFM). The probe scans the sample surface, and the interaction forces between the probe tip and surface atoms change with variations in the sample surface morphology such that surface information can be detected. Using electrochemical AFM, the morphological changes on the Cu(100) surface during the CO2RR were monitored at different working potentials (Figs. 10(b) and (c)) [57]. In recent studies, AFM has also been employed to characterize the surface structures of iodide-derived copper (ID-Cu) electrocatalysts, which include both electrochemical ID-Cu (E-ID-Cu) and wet chemical ID-Cu (W-ID-Cu) [129]. Compared to electropolished Cu (EP-Cu), E-ID-Cu and W-ID-Cu exhibited higher selectivity towards C2+ products because of their significantly increased surface roughness (Figs. 10(d–f)). Moreover, scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM), which is a distinct variation of SPM, offers real-time monitoring of local pH changes during the CO2RR [130]. Notably, SECM exhibits superior sensitivity for detecting CO, making it a valuable qualitative tool for determining CO generation during reactions [88]. Overall, operando techniques play a crucial role in characterizing the dynamic evolution of the reaction interface under working conditions, providing significant insights into the real catalytic environment at the microcosmic level. 4.2 Pulsed electrolysis techniques Pulsed electrolysis technology offers more insights into the selectivity of CO2 reduction reactions than the manipulation of catalyst properties [115]. Cu-based catalysts can efficiently reduce CO2 to C2+ products while undergoing reconstruction because of their low cohesive energy. This characteristic provides more opportunities for controlling reaction activity and selectivity through pulsed electrolysis. Researchers have conducted numerous studies utilizing pulsed potential electrolysis to enhance the selectivity of C2+ products and suppress the HER on various copper-based materials such as single crystals [131], polycrystalline copper [6,132], Cu2O [117], and preoxidized copper nanocubes [133,134]. The underlying principle of pulsed electrolysis involves the use of a rectangular potential pulse sequence. During this process, the cathodic potential remains fixed for a specific period and then gradually increases to the anodic potential during another fixed period [119]. The applied potential, pulse shape, and duration of working and anodic pulses all influence the overall performance of pulsed electrolysis [117]. Nogami et al. [135] conducted research on CO2 pulsed electrolysis on copper electrodes and successfully achieved enhanced Faradaic efficiencies for CH4 and C2H4 by varying the cathodic bias (Vc), anodic bias (Va), and corresponding pulse times (Tc and Ta, both in the second range). Pulsed electroreduction offers advantages over conventional galvanostatic electroreduction for long-term electrolysis. Currently, controlling the selectivity of the products in CO2RR remains a complex issue. Building upon the research by Kumar et al. [136], Hanrath et al. [120] investigated the influence of the temporal profiles of cathodic and anodic pulses applied to copper electrodes on CO2RR selectivity (Fig. 11(a) ). They found that CH4 production was enhanced when millisecond-level pulse intervals were employed at highly negative potentials, whereas short pulse intervals at lower negative potentials promoted CO production. Through rotating disk electrode (RDE) experiments and computational analytical modeling, they demonstrated that pulsing-dependent product selectivity is not only a mass-transport phenomenon. During the anodic pulse process, protons were preferentially desorbed from the Cu surface, leading to carbonate/COad accumulation and inhibition of the HER. Furthermore, pulse symmetry significantly influenced reaction selectivity [137]. Pulse symmetry refers to the relative durations of the anodic and cathodic portions of an overall pulse. When the fraction of cathodic duration (Fc) was 0.5, the C2 products exhibited the highest selectivity. The selectivities for CO and C2 products exhibited an inverse correlation, with the highest C2 selectivity corresponding to the lowest CO selectivity. This relationship is attributed to CO serving as a key intermediate in C2 product formation. Additionally, researchers have found that choosing an anodic potential (E a) greater than –0.5 V (vs. RHE) effectively cleans the surface of the poisoning species, thereby enhancing reaction stability. Selecting an anodic potential greater than –0.1 V enables the co-adsorption of anions, resulting in enhanced C–C coupling. Assuming that Tc and Ta durations should be sufficiently long for C–C coupling and self-cleaning, the researchers tested an asymmetric pulse profile where the two durations were at least 250 ms, each within a 650 ms period. The results showed that the overall waveform influences the reaction selectivity, with lower C2 selectivity observed for the asymmetric pulse compared to the result of Fc = 0.5. The interaction between pulsed electrolysis conditions and environmental factors is an important consideration. Hanrath et al. [138] discovered that under pulsed electroreduction conditions, the interaction mechanisms between the concentration and composition of the electrolyte and the CO2RR product distribution differ from those observed under constant potential conditions (Fig. 11(b)). At a constant potential, increasing the KHCO3 concentration is feasible for promoting the production of H2 and CH4. However, under pulsed potential conditions, where surface protons are periodically removed, CH4 becomes the main product while the production of H2 is suppressed. When KCl was used as the electrolyte, increasing the KCl concentration did not affect the product distribution during the CO2RR under a constant potential, with H2 and CO being the major products. In contrast, under pulsed potential conditions, increasing the KCl concentration suppressed H2 generation and promoted the formation of C2 products with high Faradaic efficiency. Based on a computational model of spatiotemporal concentration gradients near the electrode interface, researchers have attributed this phenomenon to the bicarbonate ion acting as a proton donor when KHCO3 is used as the electrolyte. If a proton donor is absent from the CO2RR system, CO tends to undergo coupling and form higher carbon species before protonation. Pulsed electrolysis can influence reaction selectivity, which primarily originates from the following dynamic behaviors: (1) Formation of surface oxide species [131,134,139]. When using copper-based catalysts, the anodic potential can oxidize copper, whereas the cathodic potential can reduce the oxidized copper back to its metallic state, continuously inducing surface reconstruction of the catalyst. Building on the study by Aran-Ais et al. [131] on the selectivity of Cu(100), Tang et al. [139] achieved a selectivity greater than 75% for C2 products by applying pulsed potentials to a (100)-textured polycrystalline Cu foil. They found that the reaction selectivity could be controlled by manipulating the temperature. At higher temperatures, the cathodic potential reduced most of the Cu(I) to Cu(0), favoring the generation of C2H4. At lower temperatures, Cu(I) was stable, favoring the selectivity of C2H5OH. (2) Change in the catalyst surface morphology [30,131]: In the case of Cu(100), when higher positive potentials are applied, the surface undergoes continuous oxidation and reduction, leading to the formation of cubic islands (Figs. 11(c–e)) [131]. The electrode surface undergoes structural changes induced by the pulsed potentials, leading to a shift in selectivity towards ethanol. Under constant potentiostatic conditions (–1.0 V), the product selectivity showed an ethanol yield of 8% and ethylene yield of 45%, whereas pulse-induced surface structure changes increased the ethanol yield to 32% (E a = 0.6 V). (3) Adsorption of OH species [6]: During the CO2RR under pulsed electrolysis, Kimura et al. [6] utilized XANES to investigate the catalyst's surface state. They observed Cu(OH)2 when E a exceeded 0.6 V (vs. RHE). This result indicates that pulsed anodic potential can influence the interfacial species on the electrode surface, thereby promoting the adsorption of the OH species. The presence of OHad maintains a high local pH, thereby enhancing CO adsorption, blocking H adsorption sites, and inhibiting the competing HER. (4) Removal of catalyst surface poisoning [135]: Catalyst poisoning can occur during long-term electroreduction when the reaction products are deposited on an electrode surface. In the CO2RR on copper electrodes, carbon poisoning is likely to occur due to the formation of intermediates such as formate [135]. However, pulsed electrolysis mitigates these detrimental effects. In addition, pulsed electrolysis can modulate the local CO2 concentration [119]. In addition to manipulating dynamic evolution, stabilizing the catalytic interface remains a challenge for the CO2RR, especially for copper-based catalysts. One effective strategy is to introduce additional atoms to enhance the interatomic interactions. A viable approach to prevent the reconstruction of the Cu catalyst is to stabilize Cu using silica [27]. The strong interfacial interaction between Cu and silica can effectively stabilize the catalytic interface and improve the selectivity of the CO2RR towards CH4. In addition, the interface between self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) and transition metal surfaces can stabilize the active surface and create bifunctional catalytic sites, thereby enhancing the catalytic performance [140]. Yang et al. [140] designed a 4-mercaptobenzonitrile (4-MBN) SAM-modulated Ag catalyst. Under electrochemical conditions, the chemisorption of 4-MBN can stabilize the catalyst surface and effectively prevent its reconstruction. In contrast to controlling the catalyst, the design of the electrolyzer systems can stabilize the catalytic interface. A membrane electrode assembly (MEA) reactor avoids the direct exposure of the catalyst to the flowing electrolyte, thus improving the stability of the catalyst. Sargent et al. [141] designed a self-cleaning CO2RR strategy using an MEA system. The total duration of the self-cleaning MEA system reached 236 h when the CO2RR was performed at industrially relevant current densities. 4.3 Ab initio and machine learning methods The identification of active sites is challenging because of the structural evolution of catalyst surfaces under operating conditions, even with experimental techniques that provide surface and chemical sensitivities [142]. Rapid atomic motion is difficult to detect if the time resolution is not sufficiently small. Fortunately, theoretical calculations can simulate the environment-driven surface reconstruction of catalysts, offering valuable insights for researchers. Density functional theory (DFT) and machine learning have led to significant progress in the field of electrochemical CO2RR [16,143,144]. They have been employed to accelerate the screening of suitable catalysts [145], predict possible intermediates and products [146], and study the mechanisms of surface restructuring at the atomic level [142,147,148]. External factors such as the applied potential, temperature, pH, and different adsorbates (intermediates, hydrogen, and cations) can drive the surface reconstruction of catalysts. Huang et al. [53] investigated the degradation mechanism of CuNCs driven by an applied potential using grand-potential density functional theory calculations (Figs. 12(a–c) ). A negative potential induces the adsorption of H and CO, which, in turn, drives electron transfer. The relative stability of the different facets is affected by the presence of adsorbates as the potential decreases. Sautet and Alexandrova's research group [149] determined the reconstruction mechanism of Cu(111) in acidic electrolytes under electroreduction conditions using the grand canonical genetic algorithm (GCGA), global optimization, and the grand canonical density functional theory (GCDFT). They found that the reconstruction of Cu(111) depends on the potential and pH value. At a negative potential, Cu reconstruction is driven by strong H adsorption. The same method was employed to investigate the structural evolution of Cu(100) under electrochemical conditions, where high H coverage drives reconstruction [84]. Koper et al. [150] utilized density functional theory to investigate the unique roughening of Pt step edges induced by H at low electrode potentials. In ab initio calculations, conventional models, such as the computational hydrogen electrode model (CHEM) [151], often neglect issues such as the constant electrode potential in electrochemical reactions and the multiple configurations of liquid water. To better describe solid-water interfaces, Liu et al. [152] developed a constant-potential hybrid-solvation dynamic model (CP-HS-DM). The key feature of CP-HS-DM is the incorporation of a constant-potential condition for electrons into slow-growth ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD), allowing for the investigation of kinetics in heterogeneous electrochemistry. Using CP-HS-DM, Liu et al. [153] investigated the dynamic stability of Cu single-atom catalysts under realistic reaction conditions. They observed that the adsorption of H atoms facilitated the leaching of single Cu atoms from the catalyst surface, consequently promoting the conversion of single Cu atoms into Cu clusters. Using AIMD, researchers have simulated the dynamic evolution of Cu–N bond lengths during the leaching process of single Cu atoms (Figs. 12(d) and (e)). These results indicate that with the co-adsorption of 2H, single Cu atoms can spontaneously leach from the catalyst surface in a relatively short period. Under these working conditions, the aggregation of Cu atoms forms Cu3/4 cluster structures, which serve as active sites for catalytic reactions. In further dynamic simulations (Fig. 12(f)), the increase in the Cu–N distances and decrease in the Cu–Cu bond lengths confirmed the possibility of cluster formation. Yang et al. [154] investigated the dynamic behavior of lithium imide surfaces during ammonia decomposition using molecular dynamics simulations with ab initio accuracy. In molecular dynamics, accurate electronic structure calculations are computationally expensive; therefore, researchers have constructed an ab initio-quality reactive force field by training a feed-forward neural network (NN) to reproduce the total energies and forces computed using DFT. They found that the surface structure of the catalyst changed upon exposure to reactants and was dynamically activated. The highly dynamic behavior caused by the first step of ammonia decomposition ultimately results in catalysis. For large-configuration space reconstructions, the computational cost of DFT simulations is immense, and dynamic simulations cannot be supported beyond a few tens of picoseconds. Kozinsky et al. [142] developed fast and large-scale machine learning MD to study the reconstruction process of Pd on Ag with first-principles accuracy. Theoretical calculations reproduced the transient metastable structures formed during the reaction process, highlighting the migration of a large amount of Ag from Ag(111) to surround the Pd island and the position exchange between Ag and Pd within microseconds. In summary, operando techniques can help researchers better understand catalytic interfaces under reaction conditions. Pulsed electrolysis techniques play an important role in manipulating the dynamic evolution of interfaces. Strategies for stabilizing the catalytic interface have been proposed in recent studies. In addition to experimental techniques, theoretical computational methods can simulate the dynamic behavior, facilitating a deeper understanding of the evolution mechanism of the catalytic interface. 5 Summary and outlook In this review, we summarize the current understanding of the dynamic behavior of heterogeneous interfaces in CO2RR. This review includes three main parts: the principles and classification of dynamic evolution, external environmental factors, experimental techniques, and computational methods. To develop electrocatalytic systems with superior performance, it is crucial to understand the dynamic behavior of catalysts under different operating conditions and investigate the characteristics of the active sites at a microscopic level. Reactivity arises from the interplay between catalysts and the reaction environment, emphasizing the equally important roles of environmental factors and intrinsic catalyst properties. Therefore, an in-depth study of the true effects of electrolytes, pH, and cations/anions is required. (1) KHCO3 not only serves as a proton source but also as a pH buffer. Its role depends on the type of catalyst and specific reaction pathways [11]. (2) The role of cations in the electrolytes in the CO2RR should be further investigated, including both metal and organic cations. According to the results of AIMD simulations of Au(110), two K+ ions are required to activate CO2 at the electrode [155]. The presence of K+ facilitates the activation of CO2 in the CO2RR while suppressing the HER with a cation-induced blockage kinetic effect [156]. Considering this unique catalytic behavior, extensive research is still needed to establish a unified understanding of the origin of cation effects. iii) Although anions can induce catalyst poisoning, the possibility of anion-induced surface reconstruction should be considered. In the field of operando techniques for characterizing the dynamic evolution of reactions, further advancements are required in terms of both temporal and spatial resolution. Although significant progress has been made, but there is scope for improvement. In particular, CO2 pulsed electrolysis technology allows the manipulation of catalyst morphology and properties by controlling relevant parameters, thereby regulating reactivity and selectivity. The introduction of external fields to manipulate the reactions presents a new strategy for applying pulsed potentials [157]. The application of pulsed electrolysis also necessitates consideration of the influence of external environmental factors such as the type of electrolyte and reaction temperature. Environmental factors have different effects on electrochemical reactions under pulsed potential conditions than under constant potential conditions [138]. Moreover, the combination of theoretical calculations and experimental characterization techniques has advanced microscopic-level studies of heterogeneous interfaces. Modeling structural evolution helps reproduce metastable phases and kinetically trapped ensembles, contributing to a better understanding of catalytic reactions at the atomic level [16]. Therefore, it is crucial to develop innovative computational methods and utilize the significant potential of machine learning to further enhance these studies. Author Contributions S. Yaqiong Su received his Master degree from Xiamen University in 2014 and PhD degree from Eindhoven University of Technology in 2019, and then did his postdoctoral research at Eindhoven University of Technology in 2019. He worked as a visiting scholar in 2011-iChEM, Xiamen University from November 2019 to August 2020. He is now a distinguished professor and principal investigator at Xi'an Jiaotong University. His research involves theoretical chemistry, computational catalysis and spectroscopic electrochemistry. Tiantian Wu received her Ph.D. from Technical University of Denmark in 2019, and then worked as a postdoc in Technical University of Denmark from 2019 to 2021. She also had an external stay at Prof. Núria López's group in Institute of Chemical Research of Catalonia (ICIQ), the Barcelona Institute of Science and Technology. Now she is working as an assistant professor in Xi'an Jiaotong University. Her research area is computational catalysis in metal-air batteries, lithium-ion batteries, and electrocatalysis in solid fuel cells (SOECs).

coredata.dc:description: The electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) is a highly promising renewable energy technology that can convert greenhouse gases into valuable fuels and chemicals. However, under ordinary operating conditions, significant dynamic evolution behavior occurs on the catalyst surface, which is mainly manifested as surface morphology evolution and property changes, eventually leading to changes in the active sites of the reaction, affecting selectivity and efficiency. To develop efficient electrocatalytic systems with excellent performance, an essential prerequisite is to understand the underlying mechanism of surface dynamic evolution. Studying the influence of the external environment on dynamic evolution is as important as studying the intrinsic structural properties of catalysts. In this review, we first introduce the concept of dynamic evolution and then emphasize the influence of the external environment (applied potential, temperature, electrolyte, and impurities) on CO2RR dynamic evolution. We also address the use of operando characterization techniques and pulsed CO2 electrolysis methods for monitoring and controlling dynamic evolution behaviors under working conditions, along with theoretical methods, including ab initio calculations and machine learning that can simulate dynamic behavior. Finally, we present several current challenges and prospects for the development of techniques for controlling the CO2RR dynamic evolution.

coredata.dc:title: The dynamic behaviors of heterogeneous interfaces in electrocatalytic CO2 reduction
